Sustainable carbon nanomaterials: Recent advances and its
applications in energy and environmental remediation
Soumya Ravi, Sajini Vadukumpully * sajini@aims.amrita.edu
Amrita Centre for Nanosciences and Molecular Medicine, Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences & Research Centre, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Kochi-682041, Kerala, India * Corresponding author. Tel: +91-484-2855643; Fax:+91-484-2802020.
Highlights
 This review highlights the recent advances in the synthesis of various carbon
nanomaterials from sustainable resources such as biomass
 This outline their applications in energy storage, environmental remediation and
purification
Abstract
Carbon nanomaterials represent one of the most diverse classes of materials with exceptional range of properties, which make them suitable for applications in widespread areas of research. There is an incisive need to look for new carbon nanostructures via sustainable and low-cost methods realizing their role in energy and environmental applications. Most of the conventional preparation strategies involve energy intensive conditions and hence high cost of production. In this regard, green synthesis of carbon nanomaterials via cost-effective strategies derives great relevance. Natural resources, particularly biomass; waste residues like industrial effluents and plastics can generate carbon nanomaterials. This review presents some of the recent advances in the synthesis of various carbon nanomaterials from sustainable resources and outlines their applications in energy storage, environmental remediation and purification.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
“Carbon” is a unique element in the periodic which is known to mankind since ancient times. Carbon and its compounds form the basis of all known forms of life on earth. It is one of the abundant non-metal elements present in earth crust and its diverse properties makes it remarkable [1]. The diversity of various types of carbon bonding allows the formation of different allotropes such as amorphous carbon, graphite, diamond and fullerenes. Depending on the hybridization of carbon atoms, their physical and chemical properties vary. For example, diamond is one of the hardest materials existing in nature and graphite is one of the softest materials known. Moreover, diamond has sp 3 hybridized carbon atoms forming an extended 3D network, whereas graphite has sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms forming 2D planar sheets.
Carbon materials find extensive applications in the day to day aspects of life. These materials own a long history in terms of its synthesis and applications. For instance, activated carbon in filters for deodorization in refrigerators and water purification, graphite in lead for pencils, carbon fibers for the reinforcement of rackets and fishing rods, carbon black in inks etc [2]. Carbon black fabricated via partial combustion of oils was used in inks, pigments, tattoos etc., which dates back to about 3000 years [3]. The history of synthetic graphite originated in 19 th century when it was accidentally discovered by Acheson EG in an attempt to manufacture SiC in an electric furnace from silica and amorphous carbon [4]. This lead to the development of other graphite related carbon materials, glass like carbon, pyrolytic carbon, carbon fibres etc., which found wide industrial applications [5].
The importance and uniqueness of carbon have now been extended to nanomaterials due to its exciting structural, physical, chemical, mechanical and electrical properties [6]. A whole range of dimensionalities can be found in carbon nanomaterials ranging from zero, one, two and three
dimensional structures such as fullerenes, CNTs, nanofibers, graphene and nanodiamond [7]. There also exists hierarchical structures like carbon fibre bundles, carbon polyhedral particles, carbon spherules and the discovery of all these established a world-wide research boom that is still growing [7, 8]. In this context, the development of carbon nanomaterials their properties and applications opens up new areas of research.
A new epoch in carbon based nanomaterials started in the mid-1980s when the family of buckminsterfullerene (“buckyballs”) were discovered followed by the discovery of fullerene nanotubes (“buckytubes”) [9-11]. In due course, other members of the nanocarbon family also gained attention, the latest material of interest being graphene. The 2D form of carbon, graphene was first isolated from graphite by Geim AK and co-workers [12, 13]. This discovery eventually won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2010.
Graphene is a flat monolayer of carbon atoms tightly packed into a 2D honeycomb lattice, and forms the basic building block for all other graphitic materials which can be considered as the mother form of all the other carbon nanostructures. This can be wrapped up into 0D fullerenes, rolled into 1D tube or stacked into 3D graphite (Fig. 1). Fullerenes, nanotubes and graphitebased nanomaterials are inherently connected. Researchers who produced carbon filaments had been unknowingly growing nanotubes until in 1991; Iijima S observed helical multiwall nanotubules of graphite with closed ends deposited on the negative electrode during the DC arcing of graphite [10]. The synthesis of aligned multiwall nanotube films in the presence of a catalyst by CVD was reported by Ren F et.al [14]. The popularity of carbon nanostructures arose with the discovery of fullerenes, nanotubes and graphene.
Most of these carbon nanostructures are prepared by laser ablation of graphite or coal [15-17], metal-catalyzed arc evaporation [18-20], catalytic CVD [21-23], pyrolysis [24], solvothermal
reduction [25], template assisted carbonization [26], mechanical exfoliation [12] and detonation of a mixture of explosives and hexogen composed of C, N, O and H with a negative oxygen balance so that „excess‟ carbon becomes present in the system [27]. The structures obtained vary upon the resources, decomposition temperature and deposition kinetics [21, 24]. Most of the synthetic strategies are limited to solid state reactions at relatively high temperature and pressure, which allow oriented arrangement of stable graphitic structures. Solid state strategies have limitations in terms of large scale and economical production because of their harsh conditions and low production yields [24, 26]. Recently, many efforts have been attempted to the synthesis of carbon nanostructures in solution phase. Carbon rich precursors can be transformed into various carbon nanostructures as a result of pyrolysis or solvothermal treatment [28, 29]. These methods rely on precursors such as hydrocarbons, graphite, kerosene, and fossil fuel based materials. As a result, there is strong demand for alternative preparation strategies which depend on low capital input and at the same time replacement of fossil fuel based precursors. Use of low-cost precursors such as biomass or waste residues has gained momentum in carbon nanomaterial research [30].
Biomass and waste residues are good candidates, since they are available in plenty and are enriched sources of carbon. Further, they are cost-effective and renewable. Several promising reports have emerged in the recent years on the synthesis of carbon nanomaterials from inexpensive resources through commercially viable and environmental friendly approaches [30- 32]. This review gives an overview of the recent reports on the synthesis of various sustainable carbon nanomaterials from cost effective methods and resources, briefly discussing some of their applications in environmental and energy related fields.
2. Preparation of carbon nanomaterials from sustainable resources

sections.heading: 2.1 Carbon Nanotubes and related structures
sections.text:
CNTs can be considered as graphene sheets rolled up to form coaxial tubular structures with several micrometers length. It was first observed by Iijima S while examining carbon samples synthesized by arc discharge of graphite under TEM [10]. These CNTs were multi walled. Single walled CNTs (SWCNTs) were later synthesized by his group in 1993 [11]. In the same year; Bethune D et.al reported a similar arc discharge method for the synthesis of SWCNTs independently [33]. A range of chiral structures exist in CNTs since the graphene sheets can be rolled up with varying degrees of twist along the axis. CNTs display semiconducting or metallic behavior depending on the diameter and helicity of the arrangement of the graphite rings. Molecular wires with interesting mechanical, electronic, magnetic and nonlinear optical properties can be shaped by joining together two dissimilar CNTs [34]. These properties make CNTs to be used as potential materials in novel single-molecular transistors [35], scanning probe microscope tips [36], molecular computing elements [37], gas and electrochemical storage [38], molecular filtration membranes [39], electron field emitting flat panel displays [40] and sensors [41]. The conventional synthesis methods used for large scale CNT production include arc discharge [10, 11], laser ablation [42], CVD [43] and combustion (flame synthesis) [44-46] of carbon precursors. The precursors used are mainly fossil fuel derived hydrocarbons such as methane, ethylene and benzene. This makes the production cost intensive. Hence, attempts were made to prepare high quality CNTs and related structures from relatively inexpensive feedstock like waste plastics post-consumer PE and PET, agricultural wastes (sugar cane bagasse and waste corn residue obtained after extracting the starch fraction of corn for bioethanol production) scrap tyre chips etc (Fig. 2) [47]. The general synthesis methodology involved sequential pyrolysis of
the feedstock and partial oxidation followed by CVD. The granulated solid feedstock were first pyrolyzed in a furnace in an inert nitrogen carrier gas to generate gaseous carbon containing components which was directed to a venturi where they were mixed with pre-heated oxygen containing gases or with additional inert gases. The fuel to oxygen ratio was pre-adjusted to be fuel-rich, i.e., oxygen-deficient to ensure adequate amount of carbon containing components, hydrogen and water vapor required for the growth of CNTs. This partial oxidation effluent was then directed to a second furnace synthesis reactor where they interact with fixed catalyst substrate like stainless steel screens on which the growth takes place. A high temperature ceramic barrier filter was inserted to prevent soot from entering the furnace and contaminating the substrates. The operating temperatures of both the pyrolysis furnace and the synthesis reactor
were in the range 600-1000  C.
The carbon nanostructures synthesized from corn residue exhibited twisted structures with irregular shapes and rugged surfaces. They resemble dense ropes having width of 100 - 200 nm. The nanostructures obtained from sugar bagasse exhibited well separated long (~ 50 μm), straight, smooth cylindrical structures with diameters in the range of 20-80 nm, whereas nanostructures derived from waste tyres were long and entangled braid-like cylinders with
lengths of  40 m and diameter of about 100 nm. When PE was used as the precursor, hollow
CNTs having lengths of 1-5 m and diameters of 15-80 nm were formed (Fig. 3). The properties
of these various CNMs from waste carbon feedstock were studied using Raman Spectroscopy. The CNMs showed strong peaks of the G-band, indicating the presence of graphitic carbon [48]. Besides, there were peaks corresponding to the 2D band representing the existence of parallel graphitic layers. The synthesized structures also exhibited the presence of the D-band, an indication of either disordered structures or impurities. The maximum IG/ID ratio was observed
for CNTs generated from bagasse, signifying their high quality with least disordered structures or impurities. The CNFs derived from tyre showed the least IG/ID ratio indicating lots of impurities or disordered structure. The composition of the effluent obtained after sequential pyrolysis and partial oxidation plays a major role in determining the structure and quality of the CNMs formed. The effluents of biomass wastes were found to be rich in methane and other light aliphatic compounds.
The effluents of PET generated high mole fraction of benzene and methane to a lesser extent. On the other hand, PE effluents were rich in ethylene, propylene and acetylene. The unburned hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and the hydrogen content of the pyrolysis (or partial-oxidation) effluents, could be utilized to produce syngas that can be burned, either as such or enhanced with natural gas to generate power. Hence, this is a promising technique for up-cycling waste solid materials to provide carbon feedstock for generating various carbon nanostructures and also cogenerate syngas. This addresses some of the issues such as waste disposal and ensures costeffective production of carbon nanomaterials. There are likewise reports on the one-pot conversion of plastics to CNTs which involve pyrolysis of solid polymers mixed with catalysts [49]. The decomposed products either in liquid or gaseous phases serve as the carbon source for CNT growth on the catalyst surfaces. In the presence of catalysts, plastics are decomposed by active intermediates of carbenium ions and this product dissolve into the catalyst, diffuse through and then precipitate on its surface to form CNTs. The one-pot synthesis procedure is known to be influenced by the addition of OMMT [50], zeolite [51], chlorinated compounds like CuCl [52] and activated carbon in combination with the catalysts [53]. Solid acids like OMMT and zeolite provide intermediate proton acidic sites which facilitates the breaking down of polymeric chains in the plastics, favoring the formation of CNTs [54]. Presence of chlorine radicals stimulate
dehydrogenation and aromatization during degradation of plastics resulting in more CNFs than CNTs [55].
An important parameter to be considered while choosing a renewable material as the source for high quality CNT is the low H content. This minimizes the by-product formation. Some of the carbon sources from biomass with low H content include turpentine oil [56], coconut oil [57], and palm oil [58] all of which have been used in CNT production. Camphor (C10H16O) derived from Cinnamomum camphora tree were also reported to be a good precursor for CNT production [59]. CVD synthesis for large scale production of CNT from camphor was done by Kumar M and co-workers in which single-wall, multi-wall and aligned-CNTs were generated via thermal
decomposition of camphor under Argon gas at 875 C [59]. When camphor was used as the
carbon source, only small amount of catalyst was required and the formation of by-products like amorphous carbon was found to be minimal. Cellulose is another potential resource, which is used to generate graphitic nanostructures. A simple hydrothermal treatment of cellulose at 250
C followed by impregnation of the obtained carbonaceous product with Ni salt and subsequent
thermal treatment at 900 C yielded graphitic nanostructures. This could be attributed to the
dissolution-precipitation mechanism in which amorphous carbon dissolve in the catalyst nanoparticle and get precipitated as graphitic carbon around the catalyst [60]. The oxidative treatment favored by high temperature leads to the removal of the catalyst and the formation of graphitic nanostructure with coiled morphology having high degree of crystallinity and high surface area.

sections.heading: 2.2 Graphene and related structures
sections.text:
There exist several methods for the preparation of graphene such as micromechanical exfoliation of graphite [12], CVD [61], catalyst assisted epitaxial growth [62]. In catalytic assisted growth of
graphene, the carbon sources used are expensive and catalysts are harder to prepare [63]. The most widely accepted synthesis method for graphene is the chemical reduction of GO which allows large scale production of graphene [64]. This process on the other hand has the limitation of producing graphene with defects and impurities which alter the properties of graphene [65]. Despite these developments, more cost-effective processes that give higher quality materials are still desired and remain an outstanding challenge in materials science. In this regard, an ecofriendly, low-cost precursor, camphor was employed to synthesize planar few layer graphene by CVD method on Ni foil substrates [66].
Camphor was evaporated at 180 C in a chamber and then subjected to pyrolysis in another
chamber of the CVD furnace at 700-850 C, using Argon as the carrier gas. When cooled to
room temperature, few-layer graphene sheets were detected on the Ni foils. This study unwrapped a new processing method for graphene synthesis, though there were apprehensions regarding optimizing the number of layers. In a different attempt by Ruan G et.al, less expensive and readily available carbon sources, such as food waste and insects were explored which was used without purification to grow high-quality monolayer graphene directly on the backside of Cu foils under H2/Ar flow [67]. For wastes with low or negative monetary value, they used bulk PS; a common solid waste, grass blades and dog feces. For insects, a cockroach leg was used which is again a negative value carbon source. The solid carbon sources decompose and diffuse
to the backside of the Cu foil maintained at 1050 C in a tube furnace under H2/Ar flow leaving the other elemental residues on the original side (Fig. 4). This method presents a new approach to produce high-quality pristine graphene with few defects and ∼97% transparency as confirmed by Raman and UV-vis spectroscopy. In XPS analysis, no heteroatoms were detected, suggesting its pristine nature. The hexagonal lattice structure was also confirmed by SAED in TEM. Growing
high-quality graphene is quite challenging and these demonstrations opened up new and economical ways of converting waste carbon into high value added products. High quality graphene was demonstrated to be extracted from hibiscus flower and lotus petals [68] based on
thermal exfoliation under Argon gas at temperatures ≤1600 C to get rid of the oxygen-
containing impurities. In an interesting green approach, Gupta S et.al used cane sugar, a common disaccharide to synthesis graphene [69]. In their experiment, a graphene-sand composite was synthesized by mixing the sugar solution with adequate amount of river sand. Different loading
ratios of sugar and sand were used and this was dried at 95 C in a hot air oven for about 6 h.
The sugar-coated sand was then placed in a silica crucible and heated in a furnace in N2 atmosphere at 750 C for 3 h. This composite finds application in water purification. A similar
study on graphene-sand composite used for water-purification was reported by Sreeprasad T S et al., in which graphenic material was synthesized from a cheap carbon precursor, asphalt [70]. The chemical reduction procedure of GO to produce graphene employs reducing agents such as hydrazine and sodium borohydride which are toxic and hence restricts their use in bio-related applications [71]. To overcome this problem, many natural products like proteins [72], vitamin C [73], glucose [74] etc., have been explored as reducing agents. In a typical experiment, glucose was employed as the reducing agent to synthesize graphene nanosheets (GNS) from exfoliated GO precursor in ammonia solution [74]. The formation of GNS was obvious from the solution color change (opaque brown to a dark coloration) and other spectroscopic characterization (Fig 5). The mechanism of reduction was attributed to the oxidation of glucose to aldonic acid by GO in the presence of ammonia. This aldonic acid is then converted to lactone, which contains large number of hydroxyl and carboxyl groups that form hydrogen bonds with residual oxygen functionalities present in reduced GO. Various saccharides such as sucrose and fructose could
also be used to reduce GO to GNS. Besides the mild reduction capability, the oxidized products of glucose and other saccharides play an important role as the capping reagents in stabilizing asprepared GNS. This simple approach provides a practical method for the large-scale production of water-soluble GNS, which is best, suited for biological applications.
In a novel, green and facile approach, green tea solution was used to reduce GO to produce soluble graphene [75]. The polyphenols (TPs) present in tea are biocompatible and biodegradable. This method is based on the reduction of exfoliated GO in green tea solution by making use of the reducing capability and the stabilization provided by the aromatic rings of TPs (Fig. 6). The resultant graphene was characterized to confirm the efficient removal of the oxygen-containing groups in GO. The strong interactions between the reduced graphene and the aromatic TPs guaranteed good dispersion of the reduced graphene in both aqueous and a variety of organic solvents. As the TP molecules adsorbed on the graphene are nontoxic and biocompatible, the soluble graphene synthesized by this method opens up interesting bio applications.
Glycine, a low price, environmentally friendly amino acid, has also been used as the reducing agent whereby the amine groups covalently interact with GO and under reflux conditions to reduce GO to graphene [76]. All these discussed approaches present greener alternative methods towards the cost-effective synthesis of graphene.

sections.heading: 2.3 Graphene quantum dots (GQDs) and Carbon dots (CDs)
2.3.1 Graphene quantum dots
sections.text:
GQDs are a new class of materials that have attracted world-wide research attention in the past few years due to their exceptional spin [77], electronic [78] and optical properties [79]. GQDs
usually represent few layers of graphene with a size specifically less than 10 nm [80-82]. Unlike pristine graphene which is a zero band gap material, GQDs possess strong quantum confinement and edge effects [83]. Several methods have been developed to fabricate GQDs, such as hydrothermal GO reduction [84], bottom-up synthesis [81], electrochemical [85], metalcatalyzed approaches [86], chemical synthesis [87], chemical exfoliation [88] and electron beam lithography [89]. GQDs exhibit color tunable PL properties with emission wavelengths covering the visible spectrum [90]. In a novel approach by Tang L et al, GQDs with an average diameter as small as 1.65 nm (∼ 5 layers) were prepared by a facile microwave assisted hydrothermal process using glucose as the precursor [91]. The microwave assisted process offers homogeneous and fast heating leading to uniform size distribution of QDs. This method also had the advantage of not using any surface passivating agents or inorganic additives, the sole reactant being glucose. The authors suggested that most of the carbohydrates which contain C, H and O in the ratio of ∼1:2:1 (sucrose, fructose) could also be used as the carbon source to prepare GQDs provided that H and O exist in the form of hydroxyl, carboxyl or carbonyl groups that may dehydrate under hydrothermal conditions. The size of the GQDs could be tuned from 1.65 to 21 nm by simply extending the heating time from 1 to 9 min, respectively (Fig. 7). The diameter of the GQDs increases rapidly with increasing heating time. The mechanism of GQD formation is explained by the dehydration of glucose to form GQD nuclei composed of C=C bonds followed by its growth as the heating time increases. More and more source molecules reach the surface of the GQDs and form new C=C bonds by dehydration as heating time proceeds and they grow in size. The high pressure offered by the hydrothermal condition assists orderly arrangement of C=C and thus crystalline GQDs are formed. The functional group (-OH, -CH and -C-O-R)
located at the GQD surface act as a “passivation” layer. The presence of passivation layer aids the solubility of GQDs in water as well as the efficient PL properties.
The GQDs display deep ultraviolet emission of 4.1 eV, the shortest emission wavelength among all the solution based QDs [84, 90]. The GQDs also exhibit typical excitation wavelengthdependent properties as expected in carbon-based quantum dots. However, the emission wavelength is independent of the size of the GQDs which could be attributed to the passivation layer. Fig. 8 shows the PL properties of the microwave assisted synthesized GQDs. When excited at 375 nm, they exhibited broad emission peak at 473 nm. The PL peak shifted from 473 to 519 nm when the excitation wavelength was changed from 375 to 450 nm. The various functional groups present on the GQD surface acted as “surface state” energy levels between π and π* states of C=C. These functional groups possess various energy levels resulting in a series of emissive traps. When a particular excitation wavelength irradiates the GQDs, the surface state emissive trap would dominate the emission.
With change in excitation wavelength, the surface state emissive trap that dominates the emission would also change. Since both absorption and emission spectrum are size independent, these surface state emissive traps are responsible for excitation wavelength dependent phenomenon of the GQDs. The PL quantum yields of the GQDs were found to be 7-11%. The GQDs are capable of converting blue light into white light when the GQDs are coated onto a blue light emitting diode.
Fig. 9 shows the TEM and AFM images of the GQDs, which clearly display the narrow size distribution, thickness and crystallinity. The d-spacing between the graphene layers was found to be 0.352 nm. The basal and in-plane lattice parameters as observed from the TEM and selected area FFT images characterize the graphitic nature of the GQDs. The average height (thickness)
of the GQDs as evident from the AFM image was 3.2 nm. The monodispersity of the GQDs could be ascribed to the fast and homogenous heating of water and glucose by microwave irradiation which provides uniform nucleation and growth of the GQDs [90].
GQDs in the size regime of 1-4 nm have found to be generated from a cheap resource, the pitchbased carbon fibers by an acid treatment using concentrated H2SO4 and HNO3 followed by chemical exfoliation. The stacked graphitic sub-micrometer areas of the fibers are readily broken down, leading to the creation of GQDs which are 1-3 atomic layers thick [88]. Fig. 10 illustrates the scheme of cutting carbon fibers into QDs and the resultant TEM and AFM images.
Due to the luminescence stability, biocompatibility, low toxicity and high water solubility, these GQDs function as outstanding probes for high contrast bio imaging and sensing applications. Since the PL is tunable, these GQDs find interesting applications in opto-electronics. The TEM
image of the GQDs synthesized at 120 C showed a relatively narrow size distribution between 1
and 4 nm. The HRTEM image showed high crystallinity with a lattice parameter of 0.242 nm. The HRTEM image of the edge structure of GQDs indicated that they prefer zigzag orientation more than armchair ones (Fig. 10). The way in which the sub-micrometer domain structures of sp 2 carbons present in the carbonized pitch fiber are broken determines the formation of GQDs [88]. Fig.11. shows the UV-visible absorption spectra and the PL spectra of the GQDs derived from carbon fibers. It is evident that the reaction temperatures affect the absorption properties of the as synthesized GQDs since there is a clear blue shift from 330 to 270 nm with increasing temperature. The temperature could also change the distribution of emission wavelength of the GQDs.
2.3.2 Carbon dots (CDs)
When the carbon nanoparticles less than 10 nm are amorphous in nature, they are called as carbon dots (CDs). They are characterized by their remarkable optical properties and fluorescence emissions which make them ideal candidates for numerous applications in sensing, bio-imaging and photovoltaics [83]. An innovative and simplistic method to synthesize CDs from a readily available natural bioresource, orange juice was reported. The synthesis was
through a one-step hydrothermal carbonization at a relatively low temperature of 120 C for 150
min [92]. The key components of orange juice such as sucrose, fructose, glucose, citric acid and ascorbic acid were carbonized upon hydrothermal treatment to give highly fluorescent CDs (Fig. 12). The obtained CDs displayed no toxicity and found to be promising in cellular imaging applications. They also exhibited good stability and a PL quantum yield of 26%. This strategy had the advantages of not using any strong acids or passivation agents during the synthesis and involved a green, cost-effective approach.
There have been attempts to integrate heteroatoms into the structure of CDs to improve its properties [93, 94]. The incorporation of heteroatoms into the framework of CDs allows them to have tunable electronic properties, enhanced surface and local chemical reactivity [95-97]. In an interesting study by Hu Q et al, ultra-small nitrogen (N) and sulfur (S) doped CDs (N,S-CDs) were synthesized via microwave assisted pyrolysis of rice which was used as the carbon precursor and N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC) as N and S dopant [98]. N,S-CDs showed enhanced PL properties compared to the undoped CDs. The size of the N,S-CDs was found to be about 1.4
nm whereas it was  3.3 nm for the undoped CDs. The influence of different mass ratios of NAC
to rice (NAC/rice) on the N,S-CDs was explored using HPLC-FD. It was found that higher NAC/rice ratio aided the synthesis of N,S-CDs with enhanced fluorescence emission. It was established from other characterizations like mass spectrometry, UV-visible absorption and PL
spectroscopy that the structural changes induced by doping with heteroatoms N and S has a major role in modifying the PL properties of CDs (Fig. 13).
In a similar experiment, natural hair was used as the precursor to obtain S and N co-doped carbon dots (S-N-CDs) using H2SO4 assisted carbonization and subsequent etching [99]. The formation of S-N-CDs with smaller size, higher S content and longer wavelength of PL emissions were favored by increasing the reaction temperature (Fig. 14). It was observed in this study that the S content of the as-prepared S-N-CDs increased with reaction temperature while the N content remained almost unchanged. Control over the doping allowed altering the downconversion and up-conversion PL properties of the S-N-CDs and they exhibited good luminescence stability.
The obtained S-N-CDs also retained good biocompatibility, low toxicity and excellent solubility in polar solvents. This preparation strategy opens up eco-friendly approach for the large scale production of heteroatoms doped CDs. Fig.15 shows the TEM and AFM images of the S-N-CDs.
The statistical particle size distribution of the S-N-CDs synthesized at 40, 100 and 140 C was
found to be 4-10, 2-7 and 2-5 nm, respectively with average diameters 7.5, 4.2 and 3.1 nm, respectively. There were no clear lattice fringes observed from HRTEM images indicating their amorphous nature. The average heights as obtained from the AFM results were measured to be
0.64, 0.75 and 0.67 nm for the S-N-C dots synthesized at 40, 100 and 140 C, respectively.
Similar work on heteroatom doped CDs from goose feather via microwave hydrothermal treatment is reported [100]. The size of these CDs was about 21 nm and they consisted of O, S and N atoms which the goose feathers are intrinsically rich in. They exhibited high PL efficiency of 17.1%. These goose feather-derived CDs demonstrate highly sensitive and selective detection
behavior of Fe 3+ ions with detection limit as low as 196 nM. Though several synthesis strategies for GQDs and CDs have been discussed, a major limitation associated with their production is that they do not fall under any generalized scheme of synthesis. Most of the synthesis mechanisms are diverse in nature.

sections.heading: 2.4 Porous carbon nanomaterials
sections.text:
Porous carbon nanomaterials have attracted great research interest in the recent past owing to their high surface area, open and accessible porosity [101]. These properties make them potential candidates for applications in separation, electrocatalysis and energy storage [101-103]. Biomass such as wood and cotton were reported to be suitable precursors for porous carbon structures, since they have inherent structural porosity. Besides, they are made of carbon rich organic polymers like cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin. Choice of a suitable synthesis method in combination with the characteristic porosity and carbon rich nature make them highly suitable for transformation to porous nanostructures. Porous carbon nanostructures were synthesized by microwave-assisted pyrolysis of biomass precursors such as wood, cotton and filter paper loaded with a conducting polymer polypyrrole and Fe catalyst species [104]. The precursors composed of natural polymers got transformed to highly graphitic nanostructures after microwave treatment. The conducting polypyrrole acted as the microwave absorbent, while the fast pyrolysis of the biomass precursor during microwave irradiation was catalyzed by Fe species. The catalyst species was removed by an acid leaching process using HNO3. Fig. 16 shows the TEM images of the porous carbon structures derived from various biomass. The BET surface area of the graphitic nanostructures obtained from wood, cotton and filter paper were found to be 350.95, 431.29 and 293.19 m 2 /g, respectively with pore volumes of 0.24, 0.26 and
0.33 cm 3 /g. Nanosized tungsten and molybdenum carbides were loaded on these materials and the active catalytic components were found to be well-dispersed on the hosts. Microporous carbon materials were derived by a simple carbonization and activation of the hydrolytic lignin obtained from inexpensive biomass waste sawdust [105]. The morphology and texture could be controlled by regulating the reaction parameters. The surface area of the materials were found to vary between 2000-3100 m 2 /g. They also possessed large micropore volume and narrow pore size distribution. These properties enabled good physical adsorption of hydrogen. In a recent report by Parshetti GK et al, microporous carbon structures with a high specific area of 2511 m 2 /g were obtained from EFB of oil palm trees, a lignocellulose waste. The method adopted was HTC followed by chemical activation using KOH [106]. Nonetheless, lignin present in the biomass is particularly resistant to HTC conditions and gives rise to hydrochars which are non-porous with low surface area. In order to introduce microporosity and to have significant enhancement in the surface area, a subsequent chemical activation step with KOH was adopted which resulted in chars with high surface area and micropores. These selffunctionalized and hydrophobic porous structures were found to be useful as adsorbents in CO2 capture applications. There were similar reports on the chemical activation of hydrothermally carbonized polysaccharides and sawdust which gave highly porous carbon structures [107]. A large number of micropores in their structure made them excellent candidates as selective adsorbents for CO2 uptake. 3D-porous carbon materials co-doped with S and N were synthesized from a single chemical precursor; honey suckles leaves by air drying followed by pyrolysis at
800 C in Nitrogen [108]. The high surface area and excellent electrocatalytic property make
them promising fuel cell cathode. A wide variety of diverse sources of carbon like cherry stones and olive [109], mangrove charcoal [110], alginic acid [111], rice husk [112], banana fibers
[113], peanut shells [114], waste coffee grounds [115], sugarcane bagasse [116] and natural yoghurt [117] have been explored as prospective resources for porous carbons. Similar to porous carbon, activated graphene also possess outstanding electrochemical performance because of its open and relatively flat adsorption surfaces [118]. In a novel approach by Wang H et al, hemp bast fiber (Cannabis Sativa) was used as the precursor to produce graphene-like nanosheets via a combined hydrothermal and activation processes [119]. Hemp bast fiber has a multilevel layered structure consisting of cellulose, semi cellulose, and lignin. The resulting structure comprised of interconnected 2D carbon nanosheets (CNS) with high degree of mesoporosity. Hydrothermal treatment followed by an activation process using KOH at different activation temperatures resulted in CNS with varying thickness. The thickness of the individual CNS decreased with increasing activation temperature. The thickness was found to be in the range of
50-100 nm for an activation temperature of 700 C, 40-70 nm at 750 C and 10-30 nm for the
ones formed at 800 C. These structures were unique and presented remarkable electrochemical
properties in a conventional ionic liquid electrolyte. CNSs obtained show high specific surface area in the range 1505-2287 m 2 /g, substantial volume fraction of mesoporosity (upto 58%), and good electrical conductivity. Fig. 17 shows the SEM and TEM images of the CNS obtained at
800 C activation temperatures. The HRTEM image clearly exhibits the mesoporous nature.
Porous carbon nanosheet like structures (PCNS) were derived from mixed waste plastics composed of PP, PE and PS by a carbonization process followed by KOH activation procedure [120]. The material exhibited a high specific surface area of 2315 m 2 /g and large pore volume of 3.319 cm 3 /g. This was proven to be a promising adsorbent material for separating out organic dye from waste water.
A relatively new genre of material, CGs have been receiving considerable attention due to their multifunctional properties like high surface area, good osmotic property, high water absorptivity and good elasticity [121]. The conventional methods used for aerogel synthesis rely on template assisted process, expensive chemicals and supercritical drying. In a work by Wu et al, a facile, green and template-free HTC route was adopted to synthesize sponge-like carbonaceous hydrogels and aerogels. The precursor used was watermelon rind [122]. Fig 18 shows the morphological and compositional characterization of the CGs. The 3D flexible gels were made of carbonaceous nanofibers and spheres. The porous CGs show excellent mechanical flexibility which enables them to be used as good platform for the synthesis of 3D composite materials. A composite material was synthesized by integrating Fe3O4 nanoparticles into the networks of these gels. The composites were further transformed into magnetite carbon aerogels (MCAs) by
calcination at 550 C for 4 h. The porous structure was maintained as of the original CGs, which
allowed the steady transport of both electrolyte ions and electrons to the electrode surface, giving rise to excellent electrochemical performances finding applications in energy storage device like supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 3. Applications
sections.text:
The extensive range of sustainable carbon nanomaterials derived from biomass and other low cost resources find multitude of applications ranging from environmental [120], catalytic [108], electrical [119] and to biological [92]. The following section briefly discusses some of the applications of these carbon nanomaterials in environmental and renewable energy related areas.
3.1 Adsorbents in water purification and gas uptake
The design of a competent adsorbent material for the separation and elimination of industrial pollutants from waste water is one of the major challenges in water purification. An efficient adsorbent should have fast adsorption kinetics, better selectivity and good adsorption capacity for the removal of large sized molecules [123]. A wide variety of adsorbents for the removal of organic dyes had been developed using CNTs [124], graphene [125], ordered mesoporous carbon [126] and activated carbon [127].
In a study by Gong et al [120], PCNS derived from mixed waste plastics were used as an effective adsorbent to remove MB from waste water. The interaction between the adsorbent and adsorbate was described by Langmuir adsorption isotherm.
The maximum adsorption capacity was found to be 769.2 m 2 /g which outshined other reported adsorbents like graphene [125], activated CNT [128], porous MnO2 microsphere [129] etc. Fig. 19 demonstrates the equilibrium adsorption isotherms of MB on the CNS before and after activation. The material also exhibited outstanding recyclability, i.e. even after ten cycles, adsorption capacity of 692 m 2 /g was retained and 90 wt% of PCNS still remained. The high adsorption was credited to its high specific surface area, large pore volume and numerous adsorption mechanisms including pore filling, hydrogen bonding, π−π and electrostatic interactions between MB and PCNS. Thus this study envisages a sustainable approach to utilize waste plastic and convert them into a material with crucial applications.
HTC of pine needles at 225 C and subsequent oxidation using H2O2 resulted in hydrochar that could effectively remove the organic dye MG from waste water [130]. MG is classified as a cationic dye widely used in textile, leather and paper industries as coloring agent. It is found to be extremely toxic and known to cause mutagenesis, carcinogenesis and has respiratory toxicity [131, 132]. The effluent from industries contain considerable amount of this dye which becomes
difficult to remove. In this report, the adsorption capacity of hydrothermally carbonized pine needles (HTC-PN) was improved by an activation process via oxidation to give activated hydrochar (HTC-APN) with additional functional groups. The effect of adsorbent dose, initial concentration of MG, contact time, temperature and pH on the adsorption of MG onto HTC-APN was investigated. Solution pH around 7 was observed to be more favorable for adsorption of MG on the hydrochars. Langmuir isotherm model was used to explain the adsorption equilibrium data
and the maximum adsorption capacity was found to be 97.08 mg/g at 30 C (Fig. 20).
Thermodynamic studies revealed that adsorption process is impulsive and endothermic in nature. Hence this material proved to be a cost effective sustainable adsorbent for waste water purification. One of the major environmental challenges that we face is the global warming and a key factor which contributes to this is the emission of greenhouse gases like CO and CO2 [133]. Carbon capture and storage is a prospective approach towards lessening the emissions from industrial sources [134]. Adsorption using porous material is a significant strategy adopted for the uptake of CO2 from effluent gases since the regeneration of adsorbents consumes lesser energy. Porous carbon materials are attractive class of adsorbents due to their low–cost, large surface area, better availability, hydrophobicity, resistance to acidic and basic conditions. The microporous carbon
from EFB as stated in ref. 106 has a CO2 uptake capacity of 3.71 mmol/g at 25 C and at a pressure of 1 atm (Fig. 21). These carbon materials has a hydrophobic core that makes it more suitable for CO2 capture and hence more selectivity towards CO2 over N2 gas. The adsorption kinetics was explained by the classical micropore diffusion model and the experimental data obtained fitted very well with the Freundlich equilibrium model. Strong electrostatic interactions and dispersion forces exist
between CO2 and porous carbon. There was reusability up to 10 times without significant loss in the adsorption capacity. A very high adsorption capacity of 4.8 mmol/g was obtained at 25 C for
the carbon derived from polysaccharides and sawdust via HTC and activation using KOH [107]. The presence of narrow micropores of size less than 1 nm is very crucial for the very high adsorption value. They exhibited good selectivity for CO2-N2 separation and could be regenerated easily. Hydrogen is considered as a clean form of energy and is regarded as the fuel for tomorrow. Regardless of the various existing modes of its production, the major challenge faced is the lack of effective media for its storage. Research on hydrogen storage involves developing materials with suitable thermodynamics and kinetics adept for reversible hydrogen sorption and desorption. Porous carbon nanomaterials developed by Cheng et al from sawdust by a carbonization and chemical activation procedure finds application as sorbents for hydrogen uptake [105]. The experiment was carried out at different carbonization and activation temperatures. A cryogenic hydrogen uptake capacity exceeding 5 wt% at 10 bar and 2.55 wt% at 1 bar was attained with adsorption heat of 4.1-7.5 kJ/mol (Fig. 22).

sections.heading: 3.2 Electrocatalysis
sections.text:
The use of graphitic carbon nanostructures (GCN) have attracted great deal of attention as catalyst supports in oxygen electro reduction reactions occurring in fuel cells.
Designing cost-effective electrocatalysts is the key in developing economical and high performance fuel cells and metal/air batteries. Sevilla M employed sawdust based GCNs as electrocatalyst support for methanol oxidation reactions [135]. The sawdust particles
impregnated with Ni and Fe salts were carbonized at 900 and 1000 C, respectively to obtain
GCNs. It was used as a support for making Pt electrocatalysts. It exhibited good distribution of
Pt nanoparticles and the particle sizes were in the range of 2-3 nm. CV was used to measure the electroactive surface area which was found to be 90 m 2 /g of Pt and the electroactivity was estimated to be nearly 250 A/g of Pt (Fig. 23). In another interesting study by Gao et al, honeysuckle derived porous heteroatom doped-carbon (PHC) with graphene like structures showed excellent oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity in 0.1 M KOH medium [108]. This high performance may be attributed to the synergistic effect of the high ORR catalytic sites formed as a result of hetero-doping, pore structures providing favorable reactant transport channel and better electron transfer rate caused by 3D continuous networks. In addition, they exhibited good stability and a high methanol tolerance in comparison to the commercial Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 24). Nitrogen-doped C60 fullerene derived from ginko leaves were found to be a prospective cathode catalyst for hydrogen fuel cells [136]. A novel approach in which nitrogen-doped fullerene-like carbon shells (NDCS) synthesized from fallen ginko leaves via pyrolysis in N2 was used as an excellent ORR catalyst. The strength of planar bonds in sp 2 hybrids, its rigidity, high elastic recapture, low-friction and resistance to wear offer additional advantages for the NDCS electrode to be used in FCs under both ambient and vigorous conditions [137].

sections.heading: 3.3 In Energy Storage
sections.text:
There is an ever increasing demand to develop new renewable technologies to meet the increasing energy demands. Along with this, a robust, cost effective energy storage system is equally important. In energy storage devices, supercapacitors are superior to batteries in terms of power density, good reversibility and long cycle life [138]. Genovese et.al explored the electrochemical performance of biochar derived from corn cob, an agricultural residue as supercapacitor electrode [139]. The synthesis steps involved a pre-treatment of the biomass
species, Nitrogen pyrolysis and subsequent high temperature thermal-chemical flash exfoliation. High oxygen functionality was exhibited by the material in the form of electrochemically active quinone and pyrone surface groups. The presence of highly active surface functional groups along with high specific surface area (543.7m 2 /g) resulted in an improved capacitive performance with capacitance of 221 F/g, which was 100 times greater than the natural biochar. The electrodes fabricated from exfoliated biochar had no conductive additives in it, yet showed an excellent rate capability holding back 78% of their low rate capacitance at a fast discharge value of 40 A/g. This blend of high capacitance and fast charge-discharge capability differentiate this material from most other high surface area activated carbons and other carbon nanomaterials such as graphene and CNTs. Even after 5000 successive potential cycles, the biochar electrodes were extremely robust showing only a 3% fading in capacitance. In another study, CNSs produced from waste coffee grounds were used in the fabrication of supercapacitor electrodes [115]. These CNSs had a high aspect ratio (~ 20 nm thickness to several microns in lateral size), high specific surface area of 1945.7 m 2 /g, several heteroatoms, good electrical transport properties, as well as hierarchically porous sites (size: 0.5–10 nm). The CNS-based supercapacitors showed a specific capacitance value of 121 F/g at a current density of 0.5 A/g. For CG based composites prepared from watermelon, excellent electrochemical performance was exhibited with a capacitance of 333.1 F/g at a current density of 1 A/g within a potential window of -1.0 to 0 V in 6 M KOH solution [122]. Meanwhile, they also exhibited good cycling stability with 96% of the capacitance retention after 1000 cycles of charge/discharge (Fig. 25). CNS synthesized from hemp fibre via a hydrothermal process was also well suited for low to
high (0-100 C) temperature ionic-liquid-based supercapacitor applications: At 0 C with a
current density of 10 A/g, the electrode maintains a capacitance of 106 F/g. At 20, 60 and 100 C
with a high current density of 100 A/g, there was progressive capacitance retention (72-92%) with the specific capacitances being 113, 144, and 142 F/g, respectively [119]. These behaviors undoubtedly project the materials as possessing high power-energy
characteristics. At a high power density of 20 kW/Kg and at 20, 60 and 100 C, the energy
density values were 19, 34, and 40 Wh/Kg, respectively (Fig. 26). Thus these high performance carbon nanostructures are promising candidates for usage as electrodes in energy storage devices. There are several reports on the use of carbon nanomaterials derived from cost-effective resource as anode materials in Li-ion batteries [109-111]. Porous frameworks of the carbon nanomaterials are capable of ensuring better pathways for easy accessibility of electrolytes and fast transport of Li ions. Zhang et al reported the electrochemical performance of porous carbon nanomaterials derived from rice straw as anode material in Li ion battery application [140]. Macroporous pore diameter was in the range of 2-10 μm and the presence of micropores was detected within the macroporous walls. At a cycling rate of C/2, a reverse capacity of 599 mAh/g was obtained with good cycling performance at higher C rates (Fig. 27). One of the limitations associated with porous carbons is that micro pores present in the carbon nanostructures alone is not adequate to get good rate performance at high current density, since they are not able to provide optimized transport pathways for the electrolyte. On the other hand, the presence of macro pores is highly favorable for the high-rate performance. The hierarchical porous carbon structure derived from rice straw was found to have both macro and micro pores in which the macro porous channels facilitated the electrolyte transportation and Li ion diffusion while the micro pores enhanced reversible capacity [140].
A simplistic and economical route for the preparation of a graphitic material from spongy pomelo peels (SPP) was explored which was found to be an effective anode material for Li ion batteries [141]. The method involved pyrolyzing SPP without any surfactant or further treatment. As anode material, it showed high capacity, outstanding cycling stability and rate capability with a high capacity value of 452 mAh/g at a current density of 90 mA/g which was retained even after 200 cycles (Fig. 28).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Future Prospectives
sections.text:
This review is aimed at providing the readers an overview of the various sustainable carbon nanostructures derived from cost-effective resources specifically, biomass and waste residues like used up polymer plastics. Special focus is on the strategies adopted for the green synthesis of materials like graphene like structures, CNTs, CDs and various porous carbon nanostructures. It also provides insight to some of the potential applications of these materials in renewable energy and environmental remediation. The real challenge lies in developing sustainable materials without causing any environmental concerns, whilst ensuring better yield and performance. Though there are a lot of conventional synthetic strategies adopted for the production of carbon nanomaterials, most of them have limitations in terms of large scale production, in addition to the use of expensive and toxic chemicals. This ultimately adds to the concerns of energy demands and sustainability. Production of high performance sustainable carbon is of utmost importance in energy and environmental applications, some of which have been briefly outlined in the review. The need to replace existing synthetic strategies and precursors has been well realized and a new direction in the research interest in carbon nanotechnology has emerged. It is also very crucial that these green, natural resources should also not interfere with food chain. It is quite an interesting fact that there are no generalized schemes for their development reported till
date. Most of the strategies for sustainable carbon production are miscellaneous in nature. A lot more interdisciplinary science need to emerge to explore, understand and generalize the detailed chemical mechanism for the development of several novel sustainable carbon nanomaterials and how tactically they are designed to deliver more satisfactory performances in providing clean energy and environmental applications.
